exercise: my_dict = {'a': 10, 'b': 20, 'c': 30}. Use the values() method to get all the values and print them.
student = {'name': 'Emma', 'age': 22, 'grade': 'A'}. Use the values() method to get all values, convert them to a list, and print the list.
empty_dict = {}. Apply the values() method to this empty dictionary and print the result. What do you observe?
prices = {'apple': 1.99, 'banana': 0.99, 'orange': 1.49}. Print the data type of the object returned by prices.values().
scores = {'math': 90, 'english': 85, 'science': 95}. Use the values() method to get all the scores, then calculate and print the average score.
inventory = {'apples': 50, 'bananas': 30, 'oranges': 40}. Use the values() method to get all quantities, then calculate and print the total number of fruits in inventory.
employee_ids = {'Alice': 101, 'Bob': 102, 'Charlie': 103}. Use the values() method to get all IDs, then check if ID 102 exists in the values. Print the result.
mixed_values = {'a': 10, 'b': 'hello', 'c': [1, 2, 3], 'd': True}. Get all values using the values() method, then print each value along with its data type.

data = {'user1': {'name': 'Alice', 'score': 85}, 'user2': {'name': 'Bob', 'score': 92}, 'user3': {'name': 'Charlie', 'score': 78}}. Use the values() method to access the nested dictionaries, then extract and print a list of all user scores.

product_inventory = {'laptop': 5, 'phone': 10, 'tablet': 0, 'headphones': 7, 'charger': 0}. Use the values() method to identify out-of-stock products (value is 0), then create a list of products that need to be reordered.
